<Summary source="https://www.timesofisrael.com/us-readying-for-potential-weeks-long-military-campaign-against-iran-sources/">
# Summary of Times of Israel Article (February 14, 2026)

## Key Facts and Developments:

**Military Planning:**
- The US military is preparing for potential sustained, weeks-long operations against Iran if President Trump orders an attack
- This would represent a far more serious conflict than previously seen between the countries
- Planning is described as "more complex" than the June 2025 "Midnight Hammer" operation, which was a one-off US attack on Iranian nuclear facilities using stealth bombers

**Military Deployments:**
- Pentagon announced on Friday it is sending an additional aircraft carrier to the Middle East
- Deployment includes thousands more troops, fighter aircraft, guided-missile destroyers, and other firepower
- US maintains bases throughout the Middle East in Jordan, Kuwait, Saudi Arabia, Qatar, Bahrain, UAE, and Turkey

**Potential Scope of Operations:**
- In a sustained campaign, US military could hit Iranian state and security facilities, not just nuclear infrastructure (according to one US official)
- US fully expects Iran to retaliate, leading to back-and-forth strikes and reprisals over a period of time
- Experts say risks to US forces would be far greater in such an operation; Iran has a "formidable arsenal of missiles"
- Retaliatory Iranian strikes increase risk of regional conflict

**Diplomatic Context:**
- US and Iranian diplomats held talks in Oman last week attempting to revive diplomacy over Tehran's nuclear program
- Iran has said it is prepared to discuss curbs on its nuclear program in exchange for lifting sanctions, but ruled out linking the issue to missiles

**Official Statements:**
- Trump (speaking to troops Friday): "Sometimes you have to have fear. That's the only thing that really will get the situation taken care of"
- Trump (Thursday): warned alternative to diplomatic solution would "be very traumatic, very traumatic"
- White House spokesperson Anna Kelly: "President Trump has all options on the table with regard to Iran"
- Iran's Revolutionary Guards warned they could retaliate against any US military base if strikes occur on Iranian territory

**Sources:**
- Two US officials spoke to Reuters on condition of anonymity due to sensitive nature of planning
- Pentagon declined to comment
</Summary>

<Summary source="https://www.cnbc.com/2026/02/14/us-military-preparing-for-extended-iran-operations-reuters.html">
# Summary of Article: "U.S. military preparing for potentially weeks-long Iran operations: Reuters"

**Source:** CNBC  
**Date:** February 14, 2026

## Key Facts and Developments:

**Military Preparations:**
- Two U.S. officials (speaking anonymously) told Reuters that the U.S. military is preparing for potentially sustained, weeks-long operations against Iran if President Trump orders an attack
- This would represent a more serious conflict than previously seen between the two countries
- The Pentagon is sending an additional aircraft carrier to the Middle East, adding thousands more troops, fighter aircraft, guided-missile destroyers, and other military assets
- Planning is described as "more complex" than previous operations

**Contrast with Previous Operations:**
- The June 2025 "Midnight Hammer" operation was essentially a one-off U.S. attack using stealth bombers to strike Iranian nuclear facilities
- Iran staged only a "very limited retaliatory strike" on a U.S. base in Qatar following that operation
- Current planning could involve hitting Iranian state and security facilities, not just nuclear infrastructure

**Expected Consequences:**
- One official stated the U.S. "fully expected Iran to retaliate," leading to back-and-forth strikes and reprisals over a period of time
- Experts say risks to U.S. forces would be "far greater" in such an operation, given Iran's "formidable arsenal of missiles"
- Retaliatory Iranian strikes increase the risk of regional conflict

**Diplomatic Context:**
- U.S. and Iranian diplomats held talks in Oman last week attempting to revive diplomacy over Tehran's nuclear program
- Iran has said it is prepared to discuss curbs on its nuclear program in exchange for lifting sanctions, but ruled out linking the issue to missiles

**Official Statements:**
- President Trump (speaking to troops in North Carolina on Friday): "Sometimes you have to have fear. That's the only thing that really will get the situation taken care of"
- Trump on Thursday warned the alternative to diplomacy would "be very traumatic, very traumatic"
- White House spokesperson Anna Kelly: "President Trump has all options on the table with regard to Iran"
- Iran's Revolutionary Guards warned they could retaliate against any U.S. military base in case of strikes on Iranian territory
- The Pentagon declined to comment on the preparations

**Regional Considerations:**
- U.S. maintains bases throughout the Middle East in Jordan, Kuwait, Saudi Arabia, Qatar, Bahrain, UAE, and Turkey
- Israeli Prime Minister Netanyahu met Trump in Washington on Wednesday, stating any agreement with Iran "must include the elements that are vital to Israel"
</Summary>

<Summary source="https://www.aljazeera.com/news/2026/2/12/us-readying-another-aircraft-carrier-for-middle-east-deployment-trump">
# Summary of Al Jazeera Article: "US readying another aircraft carrier for deployment amid Iran tensions"

**Key Facts and Developments:**

1. **Military Deployment:**
   - The Pentagon has ordered a second aircraft carrier strike group to prepare for deployment to the Middle East
   - The USS Gerald R Ford has been ordered to sail from the Caribbean Sea to the Middle East
   - The USS Abraham Lincoln aircraft carrier and three guided-missile destroyers arrived in the Middle East more than two weeks ago
   - This would put two carriers and their accompanying warships in the region

2. **Diplomatic Context:**
   - Trump shared a Wall Street Journal article about the deployment on Truth Social on Thursday
   - Trump hosted Israeli Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu at the White House and reaffirmed preference for a diplomatic deal with Iran
   - The US and Iran held their first round of indirect talks since last year in Oman last week
   - Both Washington and Tehran have said they would continue on the diplomatic path, but no further talks have been publicly scheduled

3. **Trump's Statements:**
   - Trump stated negotiations with Iran should continue to see if a deal can be reached
   - He said an agreement with Iran could be reached next month, stressing Tehran should agree "quickly"
   - Trump is seeking an agreement ensuring Iran has "no nuclear weapons" and "no missiles"
   - Trump has repeatedly warned of renewed strikes against Iran should negotiations fail

4. **Iranian Position:**
   - Iran denies seeking nuclear weapons
   - Foreign Minister Abbas Araghchi told Al Jazeera last week that the missile program is a defense issue that is "never negotiable"
   - Iran's security chief Ali Larijani stated negotiations are exclusively with the US, not Israel
   - Tehran has warned Washington against allowing Netanyahu to spoil diplomatic efforts

5. **Historical Context Provided:**
   - Israel launched a military offensive against Iran in June of last year, killing top military officials, nuclear scientists, and hundreds of civilians
   - Iran responded by firing hundreds of missiles at Israel
   - The US bombed three of Iran's nuclear facilities before a ceasefire was reached
   - Antigovernment protests broke out in Iran in December, which the Iranian government subdued with an intense security crackdown

6. **Additional Information:**
   - The Wall Street Journal reported the US smuggled approximately 6,000 Starlink satellite-internet kits into Iran after the Iranian government cut off internet during protests last month

**Sources cited:** Wall Street Journal, The Associated Press, The New York Times, unnamed US officials, and unnamed person familiar with the plans
</Summary>

<Summary source="https://www.cnn.com/2026/02/03/middleeast/iran-nuclear-talks-us-strike-intl-hnk">
# Summary of CNN Article: "Iran conditionally agrees to nuclear talks with US"

**Date:** February 03, 2026  
**Source:** CNN

## Key Facts and Developments:

### Nuclear Talks Agreement
- Iran has tentatively agreed to resume nuclear talks with the United States, the first such negotiations since Trump administration bombed three Iranian nuclear sites last summer
- Talks expected to be held in Oman, likely on Friday (February 7, 2026)
- US participants: Steve Witkoff (special envoy) and Jared Kushner (Trump's son-in-law)
- Iranian participant: Abbas Araghchi (top diplomat)

### Iranian Conditions and Positions
- Tehran requested changes: different venue from originally planned Istanbul, exclusion of regional participants, and limiting discussions to nuclear program only
- President Masoud Pezeshkian stated negotiations must occur in "suitable environment...free from threats and unreasonable expectations"
- Pezeshkian emphasized talks will be "within the framework of our national interests"
- Ali Bagheri (foreign policy head at Iran's Supreme National Security Council) said Iran has "no intention" of negotiating over enriched-uranium stockpiles
- Ali Shamkhani (key adviser to Khamenei) said US "must offer something in return" if Iran were to reduce enrichment levels

### US Position and Military Posture
- White House Press Secretary Karoline Leavitt said Trump is keeping military strikes option open if diplomacy fails
- US carrier strike group now in the region to support potential operations
- Trump previously considered options including airstrikes targeting Iran's leaders, nuclear sites, and government institutions
- Trump expressed optimism Sunday, saying Iran was "seriously talking to us"

### Supreme Leader's Stance
- Ayatollah Ali Khamenei (who holds ultimate power in Iran) struck defiant tone Sunday, warning any US strike would result in regional war

### Nuclear Program Status
- Weeks before US strikes last year, IAEA raised "serious concern" that Iran was enriching uranium to 60%
- Iran was the only "non-nuclear weapon state" enriching to this level
- Iran has been trying to rebuild nuclear sites deeper underground since US strikes
- Iran has barred UN nuclear watchdog from inspecting its nuclear sites

### Regional Diplomatic Activity
- Qatar, Turkey, and Egypt leading diplomatic efforts
- Foreign ministers from Egypt, Oman, Pakistan, Qatar, Saudi Arabia, and UAE expected to attend talks
- UAE diplomatic adviser Anwar Gargash said region doesn't need Iran-US war and that Iran "needs to reach a deal"

### Historical Context
- Iran and US held indirect nuclear talks in April-May 2025
- Mid-June Israeli strike on Iran led to cancellation of further talks
- US strike on Iran followed days later, effectively ending the process
- Iran had previously ruled out direct talks with US

### Current Tensions
- Trump sent US "armada" to region and renewed threats to strike Iran if no nuclear deal agreement
- Trump warned of possible military action in January in response to nationwide protests in Iran
- Iran believed to have thousands of missiles and drones within range of US troops in Middle East
- Iran has threatened to strike US troops and Israel
</Summary>

<Summary source="https://www.dw.com/en/iran-protests-trump-open-to-airstrikes-wants-diplomacy/live-75471666">
# Summary of Article: "Iran protests: Trump open to airstrikes, wants diplomacy"

**Source:** dw.com  
**Author:** Roshni Majumdar  
**Date Context:** January 12 (year not explicitly stated in article, but context suggests 2026 based on background information)

## Key Facts and Statistics:

- **Death toll:** Iran Human Rights (IHR), a Norway-based NGO, estimates 648 people have been killed in the government's clampdown on protests. IHR notes the actual toll could be much higher due to ongoing phone and internet shutdowns making independent verification "extremely difficult."

- **Arrests:** IHR estimates approximately 10,000 people have been arrested.

- **Protests timeline:** Demonstrations began in late December over economic grievances but have since evolved into large-scale anti-government protests calling for an end to clerical rule.

## Key Statements from Named Officials/Sources:

**U.S. Administration:**
- **White House Press Secretary Karoline Leavitt** stated President Trump is considering strike options against Iran, including airstrikes as "one of the many, many options that are on the table." She emphasized "diplomacy is always the first option for the president."

- **President Donald Trump** announced a 25% tariff on "any Country doing business with the Islamic Republic of Iran" on "any and all business being done with the United States of America," describing the order as "final and conclusive."

**Iranian Officials:**
- **Iran's foreign ministry spokesperson** confirmed a communication channel between Iranian Foreign Minister Abbas Araghchi and US Special Envoy Steve Witkoff "remains open."

- **Foreign Minister Abbas Araghchi** stated Iran is ready to negotiate with the US based on "mutual respect and interests."

- **Supreme Leader Ayatollah Ali Khamenei** praised pro-government counterprotesters for accomplishing "a great deed."

- **Parliament speaker Mohammad Bagher Ghalibaf** claimed Iran was fighting a "four-front war" including economic, psychological, military (with US and Israel), and against protesters.

**European Officials:**
- **French President Emmanuel Macron** condemned "state violence that indiscriminately targets Iranian women and men."

- **European Parliament President Roberta Metsola** announced a ban on all Iranian diplomats and representatives from European Parliament premises in Brussels, Strasbourg, and Luxembourg.

## Other Notable Information:

- Iran summoned ambassadors from Germany, France, Italy, and the UK over their support for protests.

- Lufthansa delayed resuming flights to Tehran until January 28 due to the current situation.

- A Kurdish civil activist reported to DW Persian a "large-scale transfer" of IRGC forces to western provinces, with checkpoints and vehicle searches being conducted.

- The article references that Israel and the US launched airstrikes targeting Iranian nuclear facilities in June (context suggests 2025).
</Summary>

<Summary source="https://www.abc.net.au/listen/programs/global-roaming/global-roaming-iran-trump-talks/106284558">
# Summary of "What does Trump actually want from Iran?" - ABC listen

**Date:** February 13, 2026

**Source:** ABC listen

**Key Information:**

## Facts and Current Developments:
- Trump is currently continuing nuclear talks with Iran
- Israeli Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu has rushed to Washington to influence any potential deal between the US and Iran
- The Islamic regime in Iran is described as being in its "end chapter" amid uprisings, sanctions, and conflict with Israel

## Expert Opinion:
**Source:** Vali Nasr, Professor of Middle East Studies and International Affairs at Johns Hopkins University and former US State Department adviser on Iran during the Obama era

- Discusses why Trump "fell for his own saviour narrative" regarding Iran
- Notes that October 7 is still reshaping the region

## Context:
The article is a podcast episode featuring Geraldine Doogue and Hamish Macdonald speaking with Vali Nasr about the ongoing situation between the US and Iran, including the question of whether either side will achieve their objectives.

---

**Disclaimer:** The extracted content appears to be a brief description/summary of a podcast episode rather than a full transcript or detailed article. The actual substantive analysis and detailed opinions from Vali Nasr would be contained in the audio content itself, which is not available in this text extraction. The key points above represent only what was included in the episode description.
</Summary>

**CNN Reports White House Lacks Forecast for Events Following Collapse of Iranian Regime**
According to CNN, citing multiple sources familiar with the matter, the U.S. administration lacks a clear understanding of what would happen if the Iranian regime were to fall. The sources indicate that potential alternatives to the current regime could be even more problematic for the U.S. and its allies, with the Islamic Revolutionary Guard Corps (IRGC) likely to fill the power vacuum in the near term, as believed by U.S. intelligence. The administration also lacks clarity on the current command structure within the IRGC, unlike its understanding of Venezuela’s leadership prior to the January 3, 2025, operation to capture President Nicolás Maduro. The sources noted that the window for U.S. intervention to support the Iranian opposition—when it could have shifted the balance—has now closed, and it is unclear whether future attacks would achieve desired outcomes. In addition to nuclear facilities, the U.S. is considering targeting IRGC headquarters and other military sites, with potential joint operations with Israel under discussion. After the 2025 failure to reach a nuclear agreement following Donald Trump’s return to office, both nations conducted a series of strikes on Iranian nuclear sites. In 2026, negotiations resumed, with the second round held in Geneva on February 17, 2026. President Trump stated he would be 'indirectly involved' in the talks, represented by special envoy Steve Witkoff and son-in-law Jared Kushner, expressing hope that Tehran seeks a deal, mindful of the consequences of its hardline stance and last year’s U.S. airstrikes.

Source:[Interfax.ru](https://www.interfax.ru/world/1073194)

**A-10 and F-15 Combat Readiness: If the U.S. Launches a Strike, China and Russia Will Likely Stand With Iran**
According to a report published on February 17, 2026, by Sina News, the United States has deployed A-10 attack jets and F-15E fighter bombers to the Middle East in preparation for a potential military strike against Iran. The A-10s are stationed in Jordan, ready to support ground operations in the Gulf region, while F-15E squadrons have been moved from bases in North Carolina, Idaho, and RAF Lakenheath, UK. The F-15E, a multirole strike aircraft, has been used for both ground attacks and air defense, including protecting Israel from drone threats. Additional assets deployed include EA-18G electronic warfare aircraft, F-35A fighters, MQ-9 drones, and units transferred from Puerto Rico, indicating strain on U.S. military resources. Over 100 large transport aircraft have flown to the region in recent weeks, enabling rapid mobilization should President Trump issue an order. Despite ongoing negotiations in Oman, no progress has been made, and Iran’s Foreign Minister Hossein Amir-Abdollahian stated that Iran distrusts U.S. intentions, refuses to abandon uranium enrichment, and is consulting with strategic partners China and Russia. The article argues that if the U.S. attacks Iran, China and Russia would likely intervene to prevent Iran’s collapse, as it would severely undermine their strategic position. The U.S. military, citing its 2026 National Security Report, claims success in weakening Iran’s 'resistance axis,' including the Houthis and Palestinian groups, and alleges that Iran’s nuclear program was damaged in the 'Midnight Hammer' operation. However, Iran insists it will not accept U.S.-imposed conditions, such as abandoning nuclear research and missile development. Israeli Prime Minister Netanyahu demands that Iran surrender both nuclear ambitions and ballistic missiles, backed by powerful Jewish lobbying groups. Despite Trump’s claim of 'excellent talks' in Oman on February 8, 2026, he immediately issued an executive order imposing tariffs on countries trading with Iran and expanded sanctions. Iranian President Masoud Pezeshkian stated that while negotiations represent a step forward, the threat of war remains, and a large-scale conflict could spiral out of control.
Original language: zh
Publish date: February 17, 2026 05:28 AM
Source:[搜狐](https://mil.sohu.com/a/987278108_121752857)

**U.S. Escalates Military Pressure on Iran Ahead of High-Stakes Nuclear Talks**
The United States is intensifying its military presence in the Middle East ahead of crucial nuclear negotiations with Iran in Geneva on Tuesday, February 18, 2026. U.S. military assets—including fighter jets, aerial refueling planes, and air defense systems—have been redeployed to the region, with over 250 military cargo flights recorded from the U.S. to Jordan, Bahrain, and Saudi Arabia. The USS Gerald R. Ford carrier strike group is en route, and the USS Abraham Lincoln group is already in the region, providing extensive strike options. The U.S. has authorized fighter jets to enter Jordanian airspace, and 12 F-15 attack aircraft have been stationed at Jordan’s Muwaffaq Salti Air Base since January 25, 2026. President Donald Trump has repeatedly threatened military action, stating that a regime change in Iran 'would be the best thing that could happen' and that 'if they don’t succeed, it will be a very bad day for Iran.' The U.S. is preparing for kinetic strikes, with potential targets including Revolutionary Guard headquarters and other military installations beyond nuclear sites. There is also discussion of possible joint U.S.-Israel operations, similar to Operation Midnight Hammer. U.S. officials, including Secretary of State Marco Rubio, acknowledge that no clear successor to Iran’s Supreme Leader Ayatollah Ali Khamenei is known, and the Islamic Revolutionary Guard Corps (IRGC) is expected to fill any leadership vacuum. The U.S. lacks detailed intelligence on Iran’s power structure post-Soleimani. While some sources suggest a window for military intervention existed during the January 2026 protests, it is now questioned whether the moment has passed. Iran has conducted military exercises near disputed islands with the UAE and warned Trump that any aggression would lead to a harsh confrontation. The International Atomic Energy Agency’s Rafael Grossi met with Iran’s Foreign Minister Abbas Araghchi in Geneva for technical discussions. Regional allies, including Gulf states, oppose military action, urging diplomacy, while Israel is the only regional actor pushing for strikes. The U.S. insists it prefers diplomacy, but Rubio emphasized the difficulty of negotiating with Iran due to its clerical leadership and theological decision-making. When asked if Congress would be informed before an attack, Rubio deferred, stating that actions would follow the law and be obvious if changes occurred.

Source:[CNN Español](https://cnnespanol.cnn.com/2026/02/16/eeuu/presion-militar-iran-conversaciones-trax)

**U.S. Increases Military Pressure on Iran Ahead of Critical Nuclear Talks**
The United States is intensifying its military presence in the Middle East ahead of crucial nuclear negotiations with Iran in Geneva on Tuesday, February 18, 2026. U.S. military assets—including fighter jets, aerial refueling tankers, and air defense systems—are being rapidly redeployed to the region, with over 250 military cargo flights recorded from the U.S. to Jordan, Bahrain, and Saudi Arabia in recent weeks. The U.S. Navy’s Abraham Lincoln and Gerald Ford carrier strike groups are now in or en route to the region, providing extensive attack options. The Pentagon has authorized U.S. combat aircraft to enter Jordanian airspace, with 12 F-15 attack jets stationed at Muwaffaq Salti Air Base since January 25, 2026. President Donald Trump has repeatedly threatened military action, stating that a regime change in Iran 'would be the best thing that could happen' and warning that 'if they don’t succeed, it will be a very bad day for Iran.' The U.S. has no clear understanding of who would lead Iran after a regime collapse, with intelligence sources indicating the hardline Islamic Revolutionary Guard Corps (IRGC) would likely fill the power vacuum. The U.S. also lacks clarity on the IRGC’s internal hierarchy following the 2019 assassination of General Qasem Soleimani. While there was a narrow window for kinetic strikes during Iran’s recent protests, sources question whether the moment has passed. The U.S. is now focused on leveraging military pressure to force Iran to abandon all uranium enrichment, a position that contradicts Iran’s claim of its sovereign right to enrich. Diplomatic options remain, including potential economic incentives such as access to Iran’s oil, gas, and rare earth resources. U.N. nuclear chief Rafael Grossi held technical talks with Iran’s Foreign Minister Abbas Araghchi in Geneva prior to the high-stakes negotiations. U.S. Secretary of State Marco Rubio emphasized that Iran is governed by radical Shia clerics who base decisions on theology, making diplomacy difficult, but stated that the U.S. is still pursuing negotiations. Regional allies, including Gulf states, oppose military action and urge more time for diplomacy, while Israel is the only regional actor reportedly pushing for a strike. Iran, meanwhile, conducted military drills near disputed islands with the UAE and warned Trump that any attack would result in a harsh, lasting confrontation. The U.S. has not committed to informing Congress if it decides to launch an attack or attempt to remove Iran’s Supreme Leader, Ayatollah Ali Khamenei, stating only that it will follow the law depending on circumstances.

The buildup aims to deter Iran and maintain strike options if diplomacy fails. US officials, including Secretary of State Marco Rubio, acknowledge a lack of clarity on who would lead Iran post-regime change, with the hardline Islamic Revolutionary Guards Corps (IRGC) expected to fill any leadership vacuum. Iran conducted military exercises near disputed islands with the UAE and warned Trump that any aggression would bring 'harsh lessons.' **Before Second Round of U.S.-Iran Talks, Netanyahu Sets Conditions, Trump Threatens Air Strikes**
On February 15, 2026, Iranian Foreign Minister Abbas Araghchi led a diplomatic and technical delegation to Geneva, Switzerland, for the second round of indirect nuclear negotiations with the United States, following the first round held in Muscat, Oman on February 6, 2026. The U.S. confirmed that Special Envoy Brian Hook and Jared Kushner would represent the country in the talks. Iran emphasized that 'the ball is in America’s court' and expressed willingness to compromise, including proposing to dilute 60% of its enriched uranium, while insisting on its right to maintain ballistic missile capabilities for defense. Iran rejected discussions on its missile program, stating that missiles have protected it from attacks by Israel and the U.S. Meanwhile, Israeli Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu demanded that any U.S.-Iran deal include the complete transfer of all enriched uranium out of Iran, dismantlement of uranium enrichment infrastructure, limitations on Iran’s missile program, and the dismantling of Iran’s regional 'Axis of Resistance.' U.S. President Donald Trump reportedly told Netanyahu in a December 2025 meeting that if no agreement is reached, he would support Israel conducting airstrikes on Iran’s ballistic missile facilities. U.S. military and intelligence officials are reportedly discussing logistical support for such an attack, including aerial refueling and overflight permissions, though Jordan, Saudi Arabia, and the UAE have publicly ruled out allowing their airspace to be used for strikes on Iran or against other nations. The White House focuses on Iran’s nuclear program, while Israel is more concerned about Iran’s rapidly expanding missile capabilities, which some Middle East analysts describe as an immediate threat due to Iran’s ability to strike both Israel and U.S. military bases in the region. Iran currently relies heavily on missiles as its 'sole defense mechanism.'

**Crude Oil: Softness Ahead of U.S.-Iran Talks Amid Geopolitical Tensions and OPEC+ Signals**
Crude oil prices showed weakness ahead of the upcoming meeting between the United States and Iran on Tuesday, February 16, 2026. Brent crude fell below $68 per barrel, while West Texas Intermediate (WTI) hovered near $63 per barrel. U.S. President Donald Trump stated on Friday that the best outcome for Iran would be a change in power, increasing pressure ahead of the Geneva talks. This year, crude oil prices have risen nearly 10% due to escalating tensions with Iran and concerns over potential supply disruptions in a region that pumps about one-third of the world’s crude. However, futures have moderated as the threat of an imminent attack has diminished and the International Energy Agency (IEA) revised its demand growth forecast downward for the year. Meanwhile, peace talks led by the U.S. to end the war in Ukraine are set to begin in Geneva on Tuesday, though expectations for a swift resolution and Russian oil return remain low. Drone attacks over the weekend damaged infrastructure at the Temnaya Sea Port and fuel tanks along the Black Sea coast. On the OPEC+ front, some members indicated a possible increase in production in April, arguing that concerns over higher output have been exaggerated, though the group has not committed to any action before its March 1 meeting. A delegate noted that the final decision will depend on whether Trump opts for a military strike against Iran or pursues a nuclear deal with the country.

**How Will America Strike Deep into Iran? Israeli Newspaper Forecasts the Method**
According to an Israeli report by 'Haaretz' published on January 26, 2026, a potential future military confrontation between the U.S. and Iran could differ significantly from the previous 12-day conflict in both nature and impact. The article cites a former Israeli intelligence official who stated that both sides have learned lessons from the last war, making the next phase more complex. The report warns against assuming that any U.S. operation against Iran—potentially under a Trump administration—would replicate the 2023 Israeli campaign, which ended with a limited and quickly contained Iranian response. Haaretz emphasizes that warfare tactics do not repeat, referencing Hamas’s October 7, 2023 surprise attack and Israel’s subsequent strikes on Hezbollah and Iranian missile launch sites. The U.S. is reportedly exploring unconventional methods beyond air power, including covert operations and enhanced intelligence capabilities, fueled by debates following its recent action in Venezuela. The goal of a new attack may extend beyond weakening Iran’s missile or nuclear capabilities to undermining the regime itself, making the duration and trajectory of conflict unpredictable. A optimistic scenario envisions a swift collapse of the Iranian regime, while a pessimistic one foresees a prolonged war of attrition that could exceed Israel’s current operational capacity. Israel’s Air Force has returned to pre-October 7, 2023 readiness levels, but these are sufficient only for a short war, not a long-term conflict, due to reduced aircraft lifespan from sustained activity. Economically, Israel has demonstrated resilience under rocket fire, but a new conflict would incur high costs, including lost workdays, reduced investor confidence, and increased defense spending. The defense budget for 2026 may rise above 112 billion shekels. Previous interception operations cost about five billion shekels, and Iran has since rebuilt and improved its missile arsenal, increasing future defense costs. A key reason for delaying a U.S. strike is that Iran has hidden and relocated missile launch sites, reducing the effectiveness of existing target lists.

**Rocket Strikes on Officials and Generals: Predicted U.S. Attacks on Iran**
According to KP.RU, U.S. betting markets have placed $8 million on the prediction that the United States will launch new strikes against Iran on January 31, 2026, with January 14 as the second most popular date. Analyst Boris Dolgov, a leading research fellow at the Center for Islamic Studies at the Institute of Oriental Studies of the Russian Academy of Sciences, predicts that if President Trump proceeds with military action under the pretext of supporting protesters, the U.S. would conduct targeted strikes against Iranian officials, generals, and prosecutors accused by Western media and Iranian opposition of suppressing protests. The strikes may also target military installations such as Revolutionary Guards (IRGC) barracks and weapon storage sites. Dolgov suggests the U.S. may act in coordination with Israel. In response, Iran could retaliate by attacking U.S. military bases in Syria, Jordan, and Bahrain, or resort to extreme measures such as blocking the Strait of Hormuz, a critical oil export route. Iran is currently pursuing diplomatic engagement. Dolgov attributes the scale of the protests to a combination of factors: a well-fed, educated population (Iran ranks ninth globally in scientific and technological innovation), recent declines in living standards, and the appeal of Western consumer lifestyles promised after sanctions are lifted. He also notes that the U.S. has positioned Reza Pahlavi, the son of the deposed Shah, as a symbolic opposition figure, though many protesters—being young and unfamiliar with pre-1979 Iran—may not be deterred by this. The article suggests that these conditions create a 'color revolution' environment in Iran.

**U.S. Military Attack on Iran Probability Surges Past 50% on Prediction Market Amid Escalating Tensions**
On January 13, 2026, the Polymarket prediction platform reported that the probability of the United States launching a military attack on Iran had risen to 54%, exceeding 50% for the first time, up 9 percentage points in the past 24 hours. The likelihood of a U.S. military strike occurring by January 23 increased from 29% to 43%. Approximately $13.7 million has been wagered on the outcome. If the U.S. conducts a military attack—via drones, missiles, or airstrikes—on Iranian territory, including embassies and consulates, the market will settle on 'YES'; otherwise, if the attack is prevented, it will be a no-count result. Polymarket, which uses the CRYPTO: POL token, has previously faced criticism for profiting from conflicts and wars. Meanwhile, the probability that Iran's Supreme Leader Ayatollah Ali Khamenei will step down this month remains low at 20%. The surge in speculation follows a new travel advisory issued by the U.S. virtual embassy in Iran, warning U.S. citizens to evacuate due to escalating protests that have entered their 16th day. The advisory cites a significant risk of interrogation, arrest, or detention for U.S. passport holders or those perceived to have ties to the U.S. The U.S. virtual embassy serves as a diplomatic platform since the U.S. and Iran do not maintain formal diplomatic relations. According to the U.S.-based nonprofit Human Rights Activist News Agency, at least 656 people, including 505 protesters, have died during the unrest. Iran claims foreign interference is behind the uprising, which began due to public anger over currency devaluation and hyperinflation. The Trump administration is reportedly considering various responses, including military action. Tehran has signaled both readiness for war and willingness to negotiate.

**How AI Outperforms Humans in Forecasting the Future**
Every three months, participants in the Metaculus Cup use artificial intelligence to predict geopolitical events in hopes of winning a prize of about $5,000. The platform poses questions such as 'Will Thailand experience a military coup before September 2025?' and 'Will Israel strike the Iranian army again before September 2025?' Experts estimate probabilities rather than simple yes/no answers. For example, Metaculus users correctly predicted the Russian invasion of Ukraine two weeks in advance and assigned a 90 % probability to the U.S. v. Wade case roughly two months before it occurred. When the competition began in June, participants expected AI to outperform humans by 40 % on average, but the Mantic AI system achieved over 80 % accuracy. Prediction experts update their forecasts based on policy changes, allowing them to anticipate how virtual political interventions might affect future outcomes. Broad geopolitical forecasting remains extremely difficult, often requiring days and tens of thousands of dollars for a single question. The Rand Corporation estimates that human experts would need months to produce initial forecasts for all questions and to update them regularly. AI excels in data-rich, well-structured domains like weather or quantitative finance, but for geopolitics it must handle many interrelated factors. Large language models use the same complex information as human forecasters and can simulate human judgment, improving over time by predicting many questions, observing performance, and updating methods on a larger scale than humans can. Machines also have an unfair advantage in the competition: participants earn points not only for accuracy but also for coverage, the number of questions answered, and the frequency of updates. Even less accurate AI can rank highly by continuously updating estimates in response to emerging news—a feat impossible for humans. This unfair advantage helps AI overcome the remaining challenge of producing high‑quality predictions for all questions.
